getTypeinfo 0.0.1
  • Get started
  • Reference

getTypeinfo: parse doc comments to obtain type information of arguments and return values

Vincent J. Carey, stvjc at channing.harvard.edu

September 17, 2025

Source: vignettes/getTypeinfo.Rmd
getTypeinfo.Rmd

Introduction

Arguments to R functions are not formally declared. The quickr package provides a protocol for declaring argument types to support transpilation. At present we do not make use of this approach.

Some conventions of documenting arguments to functions in roxygen can be used to heuristically determine argument types.

Processing source files 

library(getTypeinfo)
## Loading required package: tools
srcf = system.file("demos", "mvcal.R", package="getTypeinfo")
tt = get_types(srcf)
tt
## [[1]]
## [[1]]$parms
##                 fn   parm         type
## 1 mv.calout.detect      x       matrix
## 2 mv.calout.detect      k   numeric(1)
## 3 mv.calout.detect     Ci     function
## 4 mv.calout.detect lamfun     function
## 5 mv.calout.detect  alpha      overall
## 6 mv.calout.detect method character(1)
## 7 mv.calout.detect \\dots       unused
## 
## [[1]]$returns
## [1] "list"
## 
## 
## [[2]]
## [[2]]$parms
##              fn       parm         type
## 1 calout.detect          x    numeric()
## 2 calout.detect      alpha   numeric(1)
## 3 calout.detect     method character(1)
## 4 calout.detect          k   numeric(1)
## 5 calout.detect   location     function
## 6 calout.detect      scale     function
## 7 calout.detect gen.region     function
## 
## [[2]]$returns
## [1] "list"

Using an LLM to infer data types

When an ellmer chat instance is available, we can ask it for assistance in identifying input argument types. The prompt used was supplied with the ‘btw’ function, applied to parsed doc comments:

"Provide a CSV file with two columns, parameter names and their types, 
which you will infer from their descriptions, typically just the first 
word or phrase.  Return only one CSV with your best guesses on data 
type of parameter.  Do not use any backticks or text formatting."
if (nchar(Sys.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))>0) {
 ch = ellmer::chat_openai()
 tt2 = get_types(srcf, ch)
 tt2
}
## Using model = "gpt-4.1".
## [[1]]
## [[1]]$parms
##                 fn parameter         type
## 1 mv.calout.detect         x       matrix
## 2 mv.calout.detect         k   numeric(1)
## 3 mv.calout.detect        Ci     function
## 4 mv.calout.detect    lamfun     function
## 5 mv.calout.detect     alpha      numeric
## 6 mv.calout.detect    method character(1)
## 7 mv.calout.detect       ...     (unused)
## 
## [[1]]$returns
## [1] "list"
## 
## 
## [[2]]
## [[2]]$parms
##              fn  parameter         type
## 1 calout.detect          x    numeric()
## 2 calout.detect      alpha   numeric(1)
## 3 calout.detect     method character(1)
## 4 calout.detect          k   numeric(1)
## 5 calout.detect   location     function
## 6 calout.detect      scale     function
## 7 calout.detect gen.region     function
## 
## [[2]]$returns
## [1] "list"

Package level operations

Because the sosta package has a reasonable approach to declaring data types of arguments, we use it as an example.

tf = tempfile()
dir.create(tf)
setwd(tf)
system("git clone --depth 1 https://git.bioconductor.org/packages/sosta")
setwd("sosta/R")
fis = system("grep -l function *", intern=TRUE)
lapply(fis[1:3], function(x) {Sys.sleep(3); get_types(x, ch)})
## [[1]]
## [[1]][[1]]
## [[1]][[1]]$parms
##             fn parameter        type
## 1 shapeMetrics    sfPoly sfc POLYGON
## 
## [[1]][[1]]$returns
## [1] "list; list of shape metrics\n"
